video.title: Tkinter Course - Create Graphic User Interfaces in Python Tutorial
video.description:
Learn Tkinter in this full course for beginners. Tkinter is the fastest and easiest way to create the Graphic User Interfaces (GUI applications) with Python. Tkinter comes with Python already, so there's nothing to install!  

💻Code: https://github.com/flatplanet/Intro-To-TKinter-Youtube-Course

🎥Course created by Codemy.com. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/Codemycom

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro to Tkinter
⌨️ (0:10:32) Positioning With Tkinter's Grid System
⌨️ (0:19:29) Creating Buttons
⌨️ (0:29:30) Creating Input Fields
⌨️ (0:38:51) Build A Simple Calculator App
⌨️ (1:18:19) Using Icons, Images, and Exit Buttons
⌨️ (1:27:42) Build an Image Viewer App
⌨️ (1:49:37) Adding A Status Bar
⌨️ (1:59:45) Adding Frames To Your Program
⌨️ (2:07:49) Radio Buttons
⌨️ (2:24:36) Message Boxes
⌨️ (2:35:31) Create New Windows in tKinter
⌨️ (2:44:30) Open Files Dialog Box
⌨️ (2:56:09) Sliders
⌨️ (3:08:25) Checkboxes
⌨️ (3:17:29) Dropdown Menus
⌨️ (3:23:50) Using Databases
⌨️ (3:32:28) Building Out The GUI for our Database App
⌨️ (3:59:48) Delete A Record From Our Database
⌨️ (4:15:18) Update A Record With SQLite
⌨️ (4:42:57) Build a Weather App
⌨️ (5:04:32) Change Colors In our Weather App
⌨️ (5:16:36) Add Zipcode Lookup Form
⌨️ (5:26:22) Matplotlib Charts

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: WhoistheJC?
topLevelComment.text: Hey everyone. Just a quick PSA: if you are using python 3.x, entered the code exactly as you see it, and get a bunch of NameError exceptions, make sure that you did not name your python file 'tkinter.py.' I did not even thinking about it... It will cause the interpreter to try to import the file you are working on instead of the actual tkinter module.

topLevelComment.author: SamlinMC
topLevelComment.text:
This code don't work anymore. But try this code, i promise it will work in 2022

import tkinter as tk

class Application(tk.Frame):
    def __init__(self, master=None):
        super().__init__(master)
        self.master = master
        self.pack()
        self.create_widgets()

    def create_widgets(self):
        self.hi_there = tk.Button(self)
        self.hi_there["text"] = "Hello World\n(click me)"
        self.hi_there["command"] = self.say_hi
        self.hi_there.pack(side="top")

        self.quit = tk.Button(self, text="QUIT", fg="red",
                              command=self.master.destroy)
        self.quit.pack(side="bottom")

    def say_hi(self):
        print("This isnt a test")

root = tk.Tk()
app = Application(master=root)
app.mainloop()

replies.author: Fletcher Stacey
replies.text:
When you say no longer able to make changes, are you referring to your root window? or your actual code? (I'm assuming the former option considering the latter would indicate your program is literally breaking your ide/interpreter)

The reason for this is likely because your exit button is using .quit() on the root window, therefore terminating the tcl interpreter entirely.

topLevelComment.text:
I've done the first 3 parts and got an idea, somthing where you if you type i'm ______ it will make a label saying hi _______, i'm a program.
this is the result:

from tkinter import *



root = Tk()

def click1():
    a = False
    x = False
    y = False
    z = False
    c = e.get()
    if len(c) < 3:
        a = False
    else:
        if c[0] == "i" or "I":
            x = True
        if c[1] == "'":
            y = True
        if c[2] == "m" or "M":
            z = True
        if x and y and z:
            a = True
            b = c[3:]

    if a == True:
        label1 = Label(root, text= "hi" + b + ", i'm a program", bg = "orange", fg = "white").pack()
    else:
        label1 = Label(root, text= "I don't care", bg = "orange", fg = "white").pack()
        
button = Button(root, text = "Enter", padx = 50, pady = 50, bg = "orange", fg = "white", command = click1)

e = Entry(root, bg = "orange", fg = "white", width = 50, borderwidth = 5 )
e.pack()
button.pack()


root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.author: vidm96
topLevelComment.text:
at 0:59 , I built the button_click function a little different.:

def button_click(number):
    if not not e.get() and int(e.get()) == 0:
        button_clear()
    e.insert(END,number)

What this code does is, say you click the number 4, it checks if the contents of the entry field is equal to 0. If that's the case, it clears the entry field and adds the number you just clicked. The reasoning behind is that, when you click the buttons 0, 0 and then 4, it would make most sense to show that as 4, as 004 = 4 (if we're talking about numerical values).

The first part of the if statement also checks if the entry field isn't empty. Otherwise, if you try to pass an empty field into an integer, it gives an error.

In short, when you click a number, the code checks if the entry field is not empty, and if the numerical value of the contents in the entry field is equal to zero. If those conditions are met, it clears the field and inserts the number you just clicked. It doesn't change or enhance the calculator functionality, but just makes things look a little more neat.

topLevelComment.author: NDEnbyGamerMax
topLevelComment.text:
I kinda wish you taught us how to change the background sooner. I'm on the autism spectrum, and I absolutely hate white light. It should never be the default screen color, ever.

For my fellow autistic people , when you define your root widget, right after that, go ahead and enter the following line of code:

root.configure(backround="gray20")

I also set all of my labels like this because it looks nice when they are the same color as the background most of the time: 

myLabel = Label(root, text="Hello World!", fg="white", bg="grey20")

And my buttons and input fields like this:

e = Entry(root, width=50, fg="white", bg="black")
myButton = Button(root, text="Click Me!", fg="white", bg="grey")

You can thank me later.

And seriously, software developers, web developers, and graphic designers of the world. Make dark mode your default mode. I beg you. Nobody dislikes dark mode, but light mode is the absolute worst.

==================================

Lastly, I just got to the end of the calculator, and you didn't include a Try Exempt statement for your division. You just know some jackass is going to try and divide by zero, and you don't want the whole program to crash because they do that. In fact, since the user can type whatever they want into the input instead of using the buttons, it would be a good idea to put a Try Exempt there too in case they decide to enter in something that can't be converted to a number.

Lastly, if you're going to be doing division in your calculator, you should probably use floats instead of integers, because every time you divide and then perform an operation on the result, it's going to get floored.

Awesome tutorial, super helpful! For anyone interested, I came up with a more compact way to code the calculator buttons (from about 43:00-48:00). Here's the code:

from math import ceil
NUM_BUTTONS = 10
buttons = []

for i in range(NUM_BUTTONS):
   buttons.append(Button(root, text=str(i), padx=40, pady=20, command=button_add)
   
   i_row = 4 - ceil(i / 3)   # this will give row numbers 1, 2, 3, and 4 where appropriate

   mod = i % 3
   i_col = (mod + 2) % 3   # this will give column numbers 0, 1, and 2 where appropriate

   buttons.grid(row=i_row, column=i_col)

topLevelComment.author: CMDR Analdo Blackvoid
topLevelComment.text:
First, I want to express my gratitude for this Python course. I am absolutely new to this computer language but I’m no novice to software development generally.  To me it’s all about learning the syntax and basic commands build into the Python language, using pip and installing modules.

I realize that this is a beginner’s course, and you probably want to keep things simple. However, there are some things I don’t understand.

I’ve just been through the “Build an Image Viewer App” section and at some point, I noticed that the image_list was not defined as global inside the function where it was referenced along with the label and buttons, but the program was still working?

I then tried to remove all other global definitions and still have a fully working program without any errors nor warnings from the compiler…? (I’m using PyCharm as development system)

Several times during this section of the video you seems to get lost in the index parameter for the image list and imho its due to the complexity of the code. E.g., why the constant redefinition of the buttons and (unnecessary) parameter transfer? The program is already build using global parameters so why not use and maintain a global index parameter for the list instead?

My humble rewrite of the image viewer program below. Anybody, feel free to comment, criticize and suggest better ways to write this program in Python.


from tkinter import *
from PIL import ImageTk, Image

root = Tk()
root.title("Image Viewer")
root.iconbitmap("./monogame.ico")

my_img1 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("images/img1.jpg"))
my_img2 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("images/img2.jpg"))
my_img3 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("images/img3.jpg"))
my_img4 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("images/img4.jpg"))
my_img5 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("images/img5.jpg"))

image_list = [my_img1, my_img2, my_img3, my_img4, my_img5]
idx = 0


def update_image(image_list_idx):
    global my_label
    global button_forward
    global button_back
    global image_list

    my_label["image"] = image_list[image_list_idx]

    if image_list_idx == len(image_list) - 1:
        button_forward['state'] = DISABLED
    else:
        button_forward['state'] = ACTIVE

    if image_list_idx == 0:
        button_back['state'] = DISABLED
    else:
        button_back['state'] = ACTIVE


def e_forward():
    global idx
    idx += 1
    update_image(idx)


def e_backward():
    global idx
    idx -= 1
    update_image(idx)


button_back = Button(root, text="<<", command=e_backward)
button_back.grid(row=1, column=0)

button_exit = Button(root, text="Exit Program", command=root.quit)
button_exit.grid(row=1, column=1)

button_forward = Button(root, text=">>", command=e_forward)
button_forward.grid(row=1, column=2)

my_label = Label()
my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)

update_image(0)

root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.author: Carlton Buford
topLevelComment.text: I see what the presenter is doing.  It takes extreme maturity and love for your audience to do what he is doing here without explicitly calling out what he is doing.  He is purposely making mistakes, the same type of mistakes a beginning programmer might make or even an experience programmer might make to teach audience how we as humans learn how to learn.  When we see him making mistakes it makes us think, when we see him making the mistake, why is he doing that, it is wrong, but to know that it is wrong, forces you to think about what he is doing and why he is doing it.  For those who do not catch that he is making a mistake, until he shows you that code does not work, he goes through the logic and thinking that help you to learn how to think and do programming when you stumble on a mistake and must think about how to correct your mistake when you have no one there to help you.   I have seen so many comments about they love the patience and clarity of how he teaches, but just wish he was professional enough to have thought thinks through so that we would just see clean examples where everything works out perfectly right.........but that is not how life and learning works.   Working through his errors and understanding how and why he corrected them, gives me different ideas, on how I could have done things differently and gives me more incentive and investment in the learning, because as we move through training, i am not just trying to remember what is being taught, I am learning how to learn and how to problem solve in real time.   I call this love, because if he tells us that he is doing this on purpose, it does not have the same affect, if we think he is just like us, stumbling through things as he goes, he feels more relatable and we feel like we are learning right along with a real human being who is fallible like us and makes us, rather me more motivated to learn what he is teaching the way he is teaching it, making me feel confident because if he is making these types of mistakes and he is an expert, there must be hope for me!!!!  Kudos to the author, it does not get better than this!!!!!!!!!!

topLevelComment.text:
code for all doing calculator



from tkinter import *
# from tkinter import ttk

FONT = ("arial", 18, "normal")
OPERATORS = ("*", "+", "-", "/")

root = Tk()
root.title("Calculator")

e=Entry(root, borderwidth = 2, font=FONT)
e.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=4)

num1 = 0
num2 = 0
active_operation = ""
num1_active=True

def add(n1,n2):
    return n1+n2

def multiply(n1,n2):
    return n1*n2

def divide(n1,n2):
    return n1/n2

def subtract(n1,n2):
    return n1-n2

def clear_screen():
    global num1_active
    e.delete(0,END)
    num1_active = True

def button_click(number):
    global num1
    global num2
    global active_operation
    global num1_active
    result = 0

    if number == "=":
        num2 = int(e.get())
        print("equals")
        if active_operation == "+":
            clear_screen()
            print(add(num1,num2))
            result = add(num1,num2)
        elif active_operation == "-":
            print(subtract(num1,num2))
            result = subtract(num1,num2)
        elif active_operation == "*":
            print(multiply(num1,num2))
            result = multiply(num1,num2)
        elif active_operation == "/":
            print(divide(num1,num2))
            result = divide(num1,num2)

    if number in OPERATORS:
        print("operator")
        active_operation = number
        if num1_active:
            num1 = int(e.get())
            num1_active = False
            e.delete(0,END)

    if number not in OPERATORS:
        e.insert(END,number)

    if number == "=":
        clear_screen()
        e.insert(0,result)
        num1 = result


button_0 = Button(root, text="0", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(0)).grid(row=4,column=0)
button_1 = Button(root, text="1", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(1)).grid(row=3,column=2)
button_2 = Button(root, text="2", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(2)).grid(row=3,column=1)
button_3 = Button(root, text="3", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(3)).grid(row=3,column=0)
button_4 = Button(root, text="4", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(4)).grid(row=2,column=2)
button_5 = Button(root, text="5", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(5)).grid(row=2,column=1)
button_6 = Button(root, text="6", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(6)).grid(row=2,column=0)
button_7 = Button(root, text="7", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(7)).grid(row=1,column=2)
button_8 = Button(root, text="8", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(8)).grid(row=1,column=1)
button_9 = Button(root, text="9", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click(9)).grid(row=1,column=0)

button_plus = Button(root, text="+", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click("+")).grid(row=1,column=3)
button_minus = Button(root, text="-", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click("-")).grid(row=2,column=3)
button_multiply = Button(root, text="*", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click("*")).grid(row=3,column=3)
button_divide = Button(root, text="/", padx=30, pady=25, command=lambda:button_click("/")).grid(row=4,column=3)
button_equals = Button(root, text="=", pady=25, padx=100, command=lambda:button_click("=")).grid(row=5,column=1, columnspan=4)
button_clear = Button(root, text="cl", padx=59, pady=25, command=clear_screen).grid(row=4,column=1, columnspan=2)


root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.text:
I know this comment might be lost in the sea by how old this is, but I figured it my own solution to the calculator app(the addition only part). You let the add button use the button_click function and then when clicking the equals(=) button, it uses the button_add function, which in turn splits the e.get() into number groups (separator being the "+", in split("+")), transform each group to integers using int(num_group), then add them together, and lastly, transform the result back to string to e.insert. like this:
def button_add():
    result = 0
    num_group = e.get().split("+")
    for group in num_group:
        result += int(group)
    e.delete(0, END)
    e.insert(0, str(result))

replies.author: Chas Large
replies.text:
Just in case anyone is interested, I was using Thonny as my editor and I needed to add Pillow via the TOOLS > MANAGE PACKAGES, this fixed the above problem.
Two other issues relating to Python 3.10.
command=root.quit no longer functions, you just need command=quit
Lambda:  forward should now be just lambda:forward, no capital L and no space after the :
Hope this helps.

topLevelComment.author: plus+
topLevelComment.text:
Exit button issue 1:22:00  :  I found that the root.quit function mentioned doesn't close the window as demonstrated, but root.destroy does.  Root.quit allows you to run code that's written after the root.mainloop() line.  root.destroy destroys the mainloop. Try this:

from tkinter import *
root = Tk()
root.title("icons, images and exit buttons")
button_quit = Button(root, text = "root.quit()", command =root.quit)
button_quit.pack()
button_destroy = Button(root, text = "root.destroy()", command =root.destroy)
button_destroy.pack()
root.mainloop()
print("we bypassed the mainloop!!")

topLevelComment.author: Eslam Ahmed
topLevelComment.text:
Great tutorial <3 <3 
for image viewer, I used this fn to handle sliding
```
#current indicates the current image

current = 1
def change_image(action):
    #action is charachter "f" for forward and "b" for back
    global lbl
    global current

    if action == "f":
        current = (current+1) % 5 #Note: 5%5 = 0
    elif action == "b":
        current = (current-1) % 5 #Note: -1%5 = 4
   
    lbl.grid_forget()
    lbl = Label(image=img_lst[current])
    lbl.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)
```

replies.author: nXy
replies.text:
e.delete and e.insert's first argument is the index. so what 'e.delete(0, END)' does is it deletes everything from index 0 [first argument] until the END [2nd arg]
a code like 'e.delete(1, 3)' will delete the 1st, 2nd and 3rd index

topLevelComment.text: If you're using an IDE written in Tkinter, like IDLE or Spyder, calling root.quit can cause your IDE to crash. Use root.destroy instead. This terminates the mainloop and is safer if you call your app from another Tkinter app.

topLevelComment.author: SoooWhoCares
topLevelComment.text:
I'm currently at 3:23:50 "Using Databases". Some flaws:
1) conn = sqlite3.connect("address_book.db") doesn't create or open a table but a file that serves as database and can hold multiple tables.

2) in your tutorial you're refering to the table "addresses" that you haven't created in the tutorial, but beforehand. So everyone following your tutorial receives a "no such table" error when trying to do the same while you don't. To fix this issue the table 'addresses' needs to be created by adding this code, ideally some lines before the 'submit' function:
conn = sqlite3.connect("address_book.db")
c = conn.cursor()
c.execute(""" SELECT name FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table' and name='addresses' """)
if not c.fetchone(): # i doubt but hope youtube gets the spacing of the IF-code right
  c.execute("""CREATE TABLE addresses(
  f_name text,
  l_name text,
  address text,
  city text,
  state text,
  zipcode text
  )""")
conn.commit()
conn.close()

3) to have the table wiped on each restart 2 things work:
3.1) create a temporary database that resets itself on each program execution:
replace:
conn = sqlite3.connect("address_book.db") # an actual file is either created or edited

with:
conn = sqlite3.connect(":memory:") # exists solely in RAM but not as actual file

3.2) code to wipe the database on each program execution:
def CreateTheTable(): # you'll need to fix the spacing below in case youtube fcks it up
  c.execute("""CREATE TABLE myTableName(
  fname text,
  lname text,
  address text,
  city text,
  state text,
  code text
  )""")

try: # spacing below here too in case youtube formatting ruins it
  c.execute("DROP TABLE myTableName") # tries to delete the table and recreate it
  CreateTheTable()
except: # spacing below here too
  CreateTheTable() # if that fails (delete error due to no such file) python just creates the table instead

# With this the code used from 3:44:45 and onward works.

topLevelComment.author: Miki LMKU
topLevelComment.text:
For the Imagen viewer example, I think this is a betther implementation:

from tkinter import *
import os
from PIL import ImageTk, Image  # This library works with images


# We create this object because we have to know the ID of the image that we are working with.
# In Tkinter you can't return anything from a function used by a button. It exist 2 options
# 1. Use global variables (not recomended) 2. Use an object to store the data.
class ID:
    def __init__(self, id=0):
        self.id = id

    def __str__(self):
        return str(self.id)

    def set_id(self, new_id):
        self.id = new_id

    def get_id(self):
        return self.id


# GLOBAL VARIABLES:
IMGS_RELATIVE_PATH = "img"


# FUNCTIONS:
def get_tk_imgs_from_path(path=IMGS_RELATIVE_PATH):
    imgs = []

    filenames = os.listdir(path)

    for filename in filenames:
        if "img" in filename: # Only get images that have "img" in the filename
            img = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open(path + "/" + filename))
            imgs.append(img)

    # Adding one by one (old version)
    # my_img1 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("img/img1.png"))
    # my_img2 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("img/img2.jpg"))
    # my_img3 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("img/img3.jpg"))
    # my_img4 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("img/img4.jpg"))
    #
    # imgs = [my_img1, my_img2, my_img3, my_img4]

    return imgs


def forward_move():
    # If we are to the end of the gallery:

    if img_id.get_id() < len(imgs) - 1:
        new_id = img_id.get_id() + 1
        img_label['image'] = imgs[new_id]  # change the image

        img_id.set_id(new_id)

        # If is the last image disable the button because you can't go forward:
        if img_id.get_id() == len(imgs) - 1:
            button_forward['state'] = "disabled"
        elif img_id.get_id() == 1:
            button_back['state'] = "active"

        status_bar['text'] = f"Image {img_id.get_id() + 1} of {len(imgs)}"


def backward_move():
    if img_id.get_id() > 0:
        # img_label.grid_forget()  # clean the label if you want
        new_id = img_id.get_id() - 1
        img_label['image'] = imgs[new_id]  # change the image

        img_id.set_id(new_id)

        if img_id.get_id() == 0:
            button_back['state'] = DISABLED
        # If is the penultimate image (For example: 4 of 5), reactivate the forward button:
        elif img_id.get_id() == len(imgs) - 2:
            button_forward['state'] = ACTIVE

        status_bar['text'] = f"Image {img_id.get_id() + 1} of {len(imgs)}"


root = Tk()
root.title("GALLERY")

# Add an icon normaly is 60x60px and .ico file:
root.iconbitmap('img/icon.ico')

imgs = get_tk_imgs_from_path()

# Creating the object to store the ID of an image when we move across the gallery:
img_id = ID(0)

# Declaring:
img_label = Label(image=imgs[0])
button_back = Button(root, text="<<", state="disabled", command=backward_move)
button_exit = Button(root, text="-EXIT-", command=root.quit)
button_forward = Button(root, text=">>", command=forward_move)
status_bar = Label(root, text=f"Image 1 of {len(imgs)}", bd=1, relief=SUNKEN, anchor=E)

# Adding:
img_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)
button_back.grid(row=1, column=0)
button_exit.grid(row=1, column=1)
button_forward.grid(row=1, column=2)
status_bar.grid(row=2, columnspan=3, sticky=W + E)  # From W(west) to E(est), all across the window

root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.author: Moran Guennou
topLevelComment.text:
Concerning the checkbox glitch, my guess would be the following :

No initial value was given to the `var` variable, which means it has the default value for StringVar() : the void string.
Now at this point, tkinter is faced with a string that corresponds neither to the offvalue or the onvalue of the checkbox widget... Trying to guess what's going on, it checks the box.
Later on, when you click the button, it still packs a new label with the content of the `var` variable. The later being the void string, it prints... a void string... so nothing but with the defaut height of a Label.
If you decide to uncheck the button manually, `var` is set to the off value and everything goes back to normal.

My solution to fix this, instead of using the deselect() function :
In the beginning, set the `var` variable to either the offvalue or the onvalue. It looks like :

var = StringVar()
var.set( <either your onvalue or offvalue> )

This way tkinter is not faced with a variable with an unknown value, and everything should be fine (and the code is clearer to me)


BONUS : 'from' is a python keyword, and thus can't be used as a name for a variable. That's why the attribute is called 'from_' with an underscore in the sliders chapter.

topLevelComment.author: mEy Laul
topLevelComment.text: 1:01:46 a little bit of string parsing to make it easier for the user to see what he typed in, might be helpful in this case, no? You'd have to check for <expr1> <op> <expr2> ...<expr_n/op_n> and evaluate, whether the character-sequence of the expressions represent a purely numerical value to make the operation legal and also evaluate legal operators. You could use an ASCII-table for that because you already read your input in as a string, so you'd only have to iterate over it, check until you reach a character that represents an operator, and then check the left expression of the operator to be a valid number, if true, you check the right expression of the operator to be a number (in case of div: right operand != 0), if true, you execute the operation you found. This could be done in an evaluation-function, which depending on the case (switch(op), cases add, sub, mul, div) returns you the right result. A step further would be to evaluate a calculation with arbitrary length inputs of expressions and operators.                                                                                   Also, I'd like you to make a video about all the different possibilities of string parsing, because I think, that is one of the most crucial techniques out there and are transferrable to many different use cases. Please vote up, if you think the same. :)

image_list = [my_img0, my_img1, my_img2, my_img3, my_img4, my_img5, my_img6]
my_label = Label(image=my_img0)
my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)

button_back = Button(root, text="<<", command=lambda: forward(0)).grid(row=1, column=0)

button_quit = Button(root, text="Exit Program", command=root.quit).grid(row=1, column=1)

button_forward = Button(root, text=">>", command=lambda: forward(1)).grid(row=1, column=2)


def forward(image_number):
    global my_label
    global button_forward
    global button_back
    my_label.grid_forget()
    my_label = Label(image=image_list[image_number])
    button_forward = Button(root, text=">>", command=lambda:     forward(image_number + 1))
    button_back = Button(root, text="<<", command=lambda: forward(image_number - 1))
    my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)
    button_back.grid(row=1, column=0)
    button_forward.grid(row=1, column=2)

topLevelComment.author: Noel Gomariz
topLevelComment.text:
for the image viewer app, there is a simpler way to make the buttons work: create a variable "i" that will keep track of which image is actually displayed, it will be obviously initialized to 0. Then, inside the next_image function declare the global variables "my_label" and "i". Each time you press the button_next, "i" will increase in 1 until it gets to the limit of the list, time when it will go to 0 and start again the count. The same for the previous_image function. Hope I made it clear enough.

image_list = [ ] # list with your images
n_imag = len(image_list)
i = 0

my_label = Label(image=obama_list[i])
my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)





def next_image():
    global my_label
    global i

    i = i+1 if i < n_imag-1 else 0
    my_label.grid_forget()
    my_label = Label(image=image_list[i])
    my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)





def previous_image():
    global my_label
    global i

    i = i-1 if i >= 1 else 2
    my_label.grid_forget()
    my_label = Label(image=image_list[i])
    my_label.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)



button_previous = Button(root, text='<<', command=previous_image)
button_quit = Button(root, text='Quit', command=root.quit)
button_next = Button(root, text='>>', command=next_image)

topLevelComment.text:
from 42:00 to 1:18:00 calculator, you can use following code:
from tkinter import *
tk=Tk()
x=''
def clicked(n):
    global x
    if (n=='clear'):
        x=''
    elif (n=='equal'):
        x=eval(x)
        x=str(x)
    else:
        x=x+n
    l1.configure(text=x)

l1=Label(tk,text='',font=('Arial Bold',10));l1.grid(column=0,row=4,columnspan = 4)
d0=Button(tk,text='0',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('0')).grid(column=1,row=3)
d1=Button(tk,text='1',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('1')).grid(column=0,row=0)
d2=Button(tk,text='2',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('2')).grid(column=1,row=0)
d3=Button(tk,text='3',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('3')).grid(column=2,row=0)
d4=Button(tk,text='4',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('4')).grid(column=0,row=1)
d5=Button(tk,text='5',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('5')).grid(column=1,row=1)
d6=Button(tk,text='6',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('6')).grid(column=2,row=1)
d7=Button(tk,text='7',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('7')).grid(column=0,row=2)
d8=Button(tk,text='8',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('8')).grid(column=1,row=2)
d9=Button(tk,text='9',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('9')).grid(column=2,row=2)

add=Button(tk,text='+',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('+')).grid(column=0,row=3)
sub=Button(tk,text='-',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('-')).grid(column=2,row=3)
mul=Button(tk,text='*',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('*')).grid(column=3,row=0)
div=Button(tk,text='/',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('/')).grid(column=3,row=1)
clr=Button(tk,text='c',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('clear')).grid(column=3,row=2)
equal=Button(tk,text='=',font=('Arial Bold',15),command=lambda:clicked('equal')).grid(column=3,row=3)

tk.mainloop()

topLevelComment.text:
1:41:44 Almost the same code : 
from tkinter import *
from PIL import ImageTk,Image

root=Tk()

#Title
root.title("AAravsHarma.COM-AAHCOM")



#Image
my_img1=ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open('C:/Users/User/Desktop/AARAV BOOK ORDER CLASS 6.PNG'))
my_img2=ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open('C:/Users/User/PycharmProjects/pythonProject/venv/share/kivy-examples/demo/touchtracer/icon.png'))
my_img3=ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open('C:/Users/User/PycharmProjects/pythonProject/venv/share/kivy-examples/widgets/sequenced_images/data/images/info.png'))

img_list=[my_img1,my_img2,my_img3]
current= 0
#functions
def left():
    global current
    global myLabel
    if not current == 0:
        current = current - 1
        myLabel.grid_forget()
        myLabel = Label(root, image=img_list[current])
        myLabel.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)
def right():
    global current
    global myLabel
    if not current== 2:
        current=current+1
        myLabel.grid_forget()
        myLabel = Label(root, image=img_list[current])
        myLabel.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3)
#Defintion(s) and Placement(s)

myLabel=Label(root,image=img_list[current],text="AAHCOM")
button_left=Button(root,text="<--",command= left)
button_right=Button(root,text="-->",command= right)
button_exit=Button(root,text="x",command= root.quit)

myLabel.grid(row=0,column=0,columnspan=3)
button_left.grid(row=1,column=0)
button_right.grid(row=1, column=1)
button_exit.grid(row=1,column=2)







root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.author: Amipotsophspond
topLevelComment.text:
so one issue, from tkinter import *, ok so I was wondering why W, E, and DISABLE were not throwing a "NameError: name 'W' is not defined", so when you import * (all). tkinter provides you some syntax sugar of W="w" for you great you have less " well, this is not good for new programmer that might be confused when they W="something else" and get _tkinter.TclError: bad stickyness value "something elsee": must be a string containing n, e, s, and/or w notice how e was concatenate on to the error that's because E="e" so sticky=W+E). 
now think about if they W = Button( ... they would get TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'Button' and 'str' 
a good luck for a new programmer to track down that issue as it would hit the first sticky keyword and they would likely be looking for a issue with a button and some text causing a problem. 
syntax sugar should be deprecated, it's gatekeeping, it's lazy, and it breaks principle of least astonishment (POLA) it sets out to make it easier but makes it inconsistent. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntactic_sugar 
the whole world is benefited by more programmers its not some job it helps people bring their ideas in to reality, no one is benefited by people being frustrated or discouraged.

topLevelComment.author: Mossy
topLevelComment.text:
For people who are struggling around 1:45:00 to get the '>>' or 'Next' button to enter a 'Disabled' state:

He mentions it doesnt really matter where the if statement is placed. However, this is incorrect and probably just overlooked due to the recording happening etc. The if statement needs to be placed before the buttons as it will determine the state in which the buttons will be in. Once they are placed on the gui, the state can be changed but the button would have the removed and replaced. Similarly, we cannot place the if statement prior to us incrementing the image_number variable. The reason we cannot do this is because if we increment after the if statement is executed, then we will be able to use our button past our final point and encounter an error. At this point, the button is broken and will just keep producing errors in your terminal or console window. Ensure you place your if statement exactly where it is placed in the video to save yourself the pain of what I did and spent an extra 20 minutes on top of this 5 hour video trying to work it out haha! 

Hope this helps anyone who gets stuck where I did.
Happy coding everyone :)

topLevelComment.text:
from tkinter import *
clicker=Tk()
winnerValue=100
clicks=0
margin=Label(text="")
for i in range(2):
	margin.pack()
	margin=Label(text="")
winDisplay=Label(text="reach "+str(winnerValue)+" clicks to win!")
winDisplay.pack()
for i in range(2):
	margin.pack()
	margin=Label(text="")
display=Label(text="clicks: "+str(clicks))
def incClicks():
	global clicks
	global display
	global winnerValue
	global winDisplay
	clicks+=1
	display.forget()
	display=Label(text="clicks: "+str(clicks))
	display.pack()
	if clicks == winnerValue:
		button.config(text="You win!",state=DISABLED)
		winDisplay.config(text="Well done!")
button=Button(text="click",command=incClicks)
button.pack()
display.pack()
clicker.mainloop()

This is one of my tkinter small codes

topLevelComment.author: x0kosmus0x
topLevelComment.text: I watched the first 2 hours because I never created gui apps in python before. This tutorial seems to be good if you want to get an overview of the different widgets, but I have a suggestion for anyone who is following along: try to reuse functions instead of copying code and defining functions that do basically the same as the copied one. E. g. the calculator has four different functions that are basically the same with a different string saved in a global variable. You could pass the string as a parameter like you did with the number function, then you would only need one. The image viewer also has redundant code. You could call the same funktion for forward and backward, just put both if statements in.

replies.author: x0kosmus0x
replies.text:
@Aaron Holder  The more general function for all 4 operations could look like this

def button_opt(opt)
   first_number = e.get()
   global f_num
   global math
   math = opt
   f_num = int(first_number)
   e.delete(0,END)
   
And then you could call it like this

button_add = Button(root, text="+", podx=39, pody=20, command=lambda button_opt("addition"))
button_subtract = Button(root, text="-", podx=39, pody=20, command=lambda button_opt("subtraction"))
button_multiply = Button(root, text="*", podx=39, pody=20, command=lambda button_opt("multiplication"))
button_divide = Button(root, text="/", podx=39, pody=20, command=lambda button_opt("division"))

the rest can stay the same and you save 21 lines of redundent code.

For a dynamic image viewer you could use os.listdir to get all files in a directory. Then you could loop over this files to and create the image objects for your image list. The directory you check for images could come from user imput.

topLevelComment.author: Samuel MontyPython
topLevelComment.text: For Mac users: the 'root.iconbitmap()' does NOT allow for icons to show in the window title bar.  For Mac, what this actually does is set the app's dock icon.  It's weird that they don't cover it in the tkinter documentation.  I had to find out through trial and error and a lot of stackoverflow searches.  There are other functions available in the documentation but I haven't had any luck with the window icon at all.  If anyone figured this out, please let me know lol.

topLevelComment.author: Samuel MontyPython
topLevelComment.text: Great vid!  I just wanted to point out for Mac users:  fg color option for buttons works, but 'bg' doesn't change the background color.  You have to use 'highlightbackground="[color]"'.  and Even then, it colors the entire background of the button widget, but not the button itself.  Still trying to figure that one out.

topLevelComment.author: Hrvoje Djurdjevic
topLevelComment.text:
I didn't like the fact that pressing operator buttons deletes immediately the Entry widget, so I made this improvement: 

from tkinter import *

root = Tk()
root.title("Hrvoje's Calculator")
operation = ""
number_clicked = False

def button_click(number):
    global number_clicked
    if number_clicked == False:
        e.delete(0, END)
    number_clicked = True
    e.insert(END, number)

def button_clear():
    e.delete(0, END)

def button_add():
    global f_num
    global operation
    global number_clicked
    number_clicked = False
    operation = "add"
    f_num = int(e.get())

def button_sub():
    global f_num
    global operation
    global number_clicked
    number_clicked = False
    operation = "sub"
    f_num = int(e.get())

def button_mult():
    global f_num
    global operation
    global number_clicked
    number_clicked = False
    operation = "mult"
    f_num = int(e.get())

def button_div():
    global f_num
    global operation
    global number_clicked
    number_clicked = False
    operation = "div"
    f_num = int(e.get())

def button_equal():
    global number_clicked
    number_clicked = False
    current = e.get()
    e.delete(0, END)
    if operation == "add":
        e.insert(0,int(f_num)+int(current))
    if operation == "sub":
        e.insert(0,int(f_num)-int(current))
    if operation == "mult":
        e.insert(0,int(f_num)*int(current))
    if operation == "div":
        e.insert(0,int(int(f_num)/int(current)))

e=Entry(root, width=35, borderwidth=5)
e.grid(row=0,column=0,columnspan=3, padx=10, pady=10)
# Define Buttons
Button1 = Button(root, text="1", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(1))
Button2 = Button(root, text="2", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(2))
Button3 = Button(root, text="3", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(3))
Button4 = Button(root, text="4", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(4))
Button5 = Button(root, text="5", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(5))
Button6 = Button(root, text="6", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(6))
Button7 = Button(root, text="7", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(7))
Button8 = Button(root, text="8", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(8))
Button9 = Button(root, text="9", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(9))
Button0 = Button(root, text="0", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(0))
Button_add = Button(root, text="+", padx=39, pady=20, command=button_add)
Button_equal = Button(root, text="=", padx=90, pady=20, command=button_equal)
Button_clear = Button(root, text="Clear", padx=79, pady=20, command=button_clear)
Button_subtract = Button(root, text="-", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_sub)
Button_multiply = Button(root, text="*", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_mult)
Button_divide = Button(root, text="/", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_div)
# Put buttons on the screen
Button1.grid(row=3, column=0)
Button2.grid(row=3, column=1)
Button3.grid(row=3, column=2)

Button4.grid(row=2, column=0)
Button5.grid(row=2, column=1)
Button6.grid(row=2, column=2)

Button7.grid(row=1, column=0)
Button8.grid(row=1, column=1)
Button9.grid(row=1, column=2)

Button0.grid(row=4, column=0)
Button_clear.grid(row=4,column=1, columnspan=2)
Button_add.grid(row=5,column=0)
Button_equal.grid(row=5,column=1, columnspan=2)

Button_subtract.grid(row=6, column=0)
Button_multiply.grid(row=6, column=1)
Button_divide.grid(row=6, column=2)

root.mainloop()

topLevelComment.text:
I modified my calculator to be small and this is my code------
from tkinter import *
r = Tk()
r.title('Calculator')
e = Entry(r, width=20,borderwidth=5)
e.grid(row=0,column=0,columnspan=3,padx=3,pady=3)
def button_click(number):
    current = e.get()
    e.delete(0, END)
    e.insert(0, str(current) + str(number))

def button_clear():
    e.delete(0, END)
def button_add():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "addition"
    f_num = int(first_number)
    e.delete(0,END)

def button_equal():
    second_number = e.get()
    e.delete(0, END)
    if math == 'addition':
        e.insert(0, f_num + int(second_number))
    if math == 'subtraction':
        e.insert(0, f_num - int(second_number))
    if math == 'division':
        e.insert(0, f_num / int(second_number))
    if math == 'multiplication':
        e.insert(0, f_num * int(second_number))


def btn_minus():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "subtraction"
    f_num = int(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)
def btn_divide():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "division"
    f_num = int(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)
def btn_multiply():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "multiplication"
    f_num = int(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)



btn1 = Button(r,text='1',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(1))
btn2 = Button(r,text='2',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(2))
btn3 = Button(r,text='3',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(3))
btn4 = Button(r,text='4',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(4))
btn5 = Button(r,text='5',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(5))
btn6 = Button(r,text='6',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(6))
btn7 = Button(r,text='7',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(7))
btn8 = Button(r,text='8',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(8))
btn9 = Button(r,text='9',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(9))
btn0 = Button(r,text='0',pady=14,padx=14,command=lambda: button_click(0))
btn_add = Button(r,text='+',pady=14,padx=14,command=button_add)
btn_equal = Button(r,text='=',pady=14,padx=14,command=button_equal)
btn_clear = Button(r,text='clear',pady=14,padx=14,command=button_clear)
btn_off = Button(r, text='off',pady=14,padx=14,command=quit)

btn_minus = Button(r,text='-',pady=14,padx=14,command=btn_minus)
btn_divide = Button(r,text='/',pady=14,padx=14,command=btn_divide)
btn_multiply = Button(r,text='x',pady=14,padx=14,command=btn_multiply)



btn1.grid(row=3,column=0)
btn2.grid(row=3,column=1)
btn3.grid(row=3,column=2)

btn4.grid(row=2,column=0)
btn5.grid(row=2,column=2)
btn6.grid(row=2,column=1)

btn7.grid(row=1,column=0)
btn8.grid(row=1,column=1)
btn9.grid(row=1,column=2)

btn0.grid(row=4,column=1)
btn_add.grid(row=0,column=3)
btn_equal.grid(row=4,column=2)
btn_clear.grid(row=4,column=0)

btn_minus.grid(row=1,column=3)
btn_multiply.grid(row=2,column=3)
btn_divide.grid(row=3,column=3)

topLevelComment.author: Cube
topLevelComment.text:
56:00 If you're feeling lazy and don't want to do all this, you only have to change
this:

e.insert(0, number)

to this:

e.insert(END, number)

and it will (for example) say 123 if you click 1, then 2, then 3.


and to make the clear button work you can do this instead:

def button_click(number):
    if number == 'cl':
        e.delete(0, END)
    else:
        e.insert(END, num)
of course, that means that the clear button declaration should now say this:


button_clear = Button(root, text="Clear", padx=79, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click('cl'))

replies.text:
I'm getting the same issue. It's not displaying the buttons. I noticed he has the buttons on the bottom of his editor. When I commented them out it didn't work but when I decommented it worked. I suggest just creating the buttons out side the forward function.  Here's my code that I used. Let me know if it works. 

from tkinter import *
from PIL import ImageTk, Image

window = Tk()


my_img1 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("muscle.png"))
my_img2 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("AriPark.png"))
my_img3 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("Levilockers.png"))
my_img4 = ImageTk.PhotoImage(Image.open("Levischool.png"))

img_list = [my_img1, my_img2, my_img3, my_img4 ]



my_label = Label(image = my_img1)
my_label.grid(row = 0, column = 0, columnspan = 5)
def forward (img_number):
	
		global my_label
		global button_forward
		global button_back
	
		my_label.grid_forget()
		my_label = Label(image = img_list [img_number -1])
		my_label.grid(row = 0, column = 0, columnspan = 5)
		button_forward = Button(window, text = ">>", command = lambda: forward (img_number +1))
	
		button_back = Button(window, text = "<<", command = lambda: back (img_number-1))

		my_label.grid(row = 0, column = 0, columnspan = 5)
		button_back.grid( row = 1, column = 0)
		button_forward.grid(row = 1, column =2)
		
		if img_number == len(img_list)-1:
			button_forward = Button(window, text = ">>", state = DISABLED)

def back(): 
	global button_forward
	global button_back
	global my_label
	
button_back = Button(window, text = "<<", command = back)
button_exit = Button(window, text ="Exit", command = window.quit)
#button_forward = Button(window, text = ">>", command = lambda: forward(2))

button_back.grid( row = 1, column = 0)
button_exit.grid(row =1, column = 1)
#button_forward.grid(row = 1, column =2)









window.mainloop()

topLevelComment.author: David Todd
topLevelComment.text:
First, thank you so much for the GUI intro. Totally new to python and been learning during quarantine for the last few days. This was incredibly helpful.
Second, is there any way to place button functions in modules you can call from? I like to build big projects for practice(big for me at least), and being able to section off functions and import them to my main app.py helps alot.

Finally, and there may be a reason you didn't do this, but for the image viewer, you don't need to redefine the whole buttons within their command functions. You can just have the label select from you image list using image= image_list[x], then have the buttons increase or decrease the global variable x to have them move up or down the list by having the buttons set x= x+1, or -1 for backwards. to have them loop, just put that in an if function "if x>3: x=x+1" plus "if x ==3: x=0" for forwards, and use -3 for backwards. you can even have that update automatically if you define a variable that is always equal to the length of your image list using index()... I'm a beginner, big time, but when I saw you doing this is hurt me to think about and then did this with half the lines and less mind spinning. final code was like 100 characters and several lines shorter, and didn't even need an argument from the button commands or to global the buttons themselves inside their own commands so you don't run into weird redefine errors later.

topLevelComment.author: Sathish Selvan
topLevelComment.text:
i used eval func
def button_symbol(symbol):
    current = e.get()
    e.delete(0,END)
    e.insert(0,str(current)+symbol)
def button_equal():
    current = e.get()
    s = eval(current)
    e.delete(0,END)
    e.insert(0,s)

thats it :)

topLevelComment.author: David Peebles
topLevelComment.text: 1:18:21 I found a couple of things while doing the icon code on Linux.  1. Tkinter on Linux doesn't allow .ico files so you must convert them to .xbm.  You also need to preface the path with @ (e.g., root.iconbitmap('@/home/images/glider.xbm')).  Finally, the root.quit command doesn't seem to work but root.destroy does (e.g., button_quit = Button(root, text="Quit", command=root.destroy)).  Many thanks for these great videos.  I love your style.

topLevelComment.author: Med SMATI
topLevelComment.text:
Hello Mr John,
I want to give you the explanation of the strange behavior of checkbutton when we use string value instead of integer value.
the line of code concerned is:
c = Checkbutton(root, text="Check this ...", variable=var, onvalue="On", offvalue="Off")
when you used an integer value, possibles values are 0 or 1, and the default value for integer is 0, it is why by default it is unchecked; but when you used string value and you defined the values "On" and "Off", the default value for a string is an empty string "" which doesn't exist between the 2 values you choosed; that means that the checkbutton starts with neither the value corresponding to unchecked nor the value corresponding to checked.
To correct this, we can initialize the string variable with, for the example, "On" (if we want it to be checked initialy) or "Off" (if we want it to be unchecked initialy).
var.set("Off")
cordially

For anyone here on Mac, that's having trouble getting the radio buttons to show, I managed to sort it by simply packing it on a different line. No idea why it was not appearing when doing it the way John originally did, but oh well.

button1 = Radiobutton(root, text = "option 1", variable = r, value = 1 )
button2 = Radiobutton(root, text = "option 1", variable = r, value = 2 )

button1.pack()
button2.pack()

replies.author: Bradley
replies.text: What code editor are you using? In VScode you can right-click the image in the explorer and click "Copy Path", assuming the images are in the same root folder as your code. Otherwise, go into Finder,  hit Command-i to open Get Info, then copy and paste the bit that after "Where: ". It should look like a file structure. Once you paste it, it'll turn into a file path that you can use in your project (e.g. "/Users/yourname/Desktop/project_folder/photo_img.png")

replies.author: SA.93
replies.text: After you use, for example, the addition button, math variable will be equal to the string "addition", after that, when you press equal, it'll go to the button_equal method and since your math = "addition", then according to the if statement, it'll use the + operation. Basically it'll just save a string into math variable (the math operator you used) and use it in the if statements in the equal method.

3:40:02 if someone has a problem here with *"AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'delete'"*

Don't do
l_name = Entry(root, width=30).grid(row=1, column=1, padx=20)

but 
l_name = Entry(root, width=30)
l_name.grid(row=1, column=1, padx=20)

it works then

topLevelComment.text:
Sorry, I dont want to come off as a know it all, but i have a tip i think it can be of use. When you want to access elements in a list or tuple (and i believe with dictionaries, but i'm not sure) from the end to the beginning you can pass on a negative index. 
Example: a = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5) 
a[-1] = 5
a[-2] = 4 
... and so on. This saves you the time and trouble of counting or thinking of the length of your list or tuple to know where the last element, second to last element and so on, are. I hope you all find this useful.

topLevelComment.author: Paul Taylor
topLevelComment.text: if anyone was wondering at 2:57:25 why the from_ parameter needs an underscore at the end, it's because "from" by itself is a reserved word in Python (used in things like from Tkinter import messagebox, for example). Using a reserved word to have a completely different meaning would be problematic, so the developers of Tkinter added an underscore at the end to differentiate it from the original "from".

topLevelComment.author: Paul Taylor
topLevelComment.text:
note for around 1:02:04 when he decides to use a global variable: if you want to avoid using globals (and just make the whole calculator project a lot simpler), you could just have the calculator show the entire expression when you type it, instead of clearing the Entry field when one of the arithmetic operator buttons are pressed. This way, your program doesn't need to remember anything, and can just read what's in the Entry field when the equal button is pressed, and use eval(expresion_as_a_str) to evaluate the whole function easily. 
I'd also recommend making a function to create all the buttons so that you don't need to copy basically the same line a bunch of times only to change the value and placement of the button.
Using partials (from functools import partial, then command=partial(myFunction, argument)) is also a helpful way to pass arguments to the button commands.
With all this, the calculator project becomes a lot shorter to code and has all the same functionality. I wrote one that supports addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponentiation, decimals, and order of operations in 50 PEP 8-compliant lines haha, and I'm sure it could be done in fewer!

Subscribed and loved the video; took me literally one week to finish the entire series.  Your explanation has been super clear, down to earth, and straight out funny at times.  
In future, here are list of interesting topics which I think your audience might benefit (at the very least I will selfishly benefit):

(2) Django and its interaction with tkinter (if this is remotely possible); if Django is a standalone type of GUI, then coverage from you will be amazing!

topLevelComment.author: J Lawrence Buell iv
topLevelComment.text: I'm really appreciating these courses as I learn Python. Currently watching the Calculator video(s). For the record, an RPN calculator is far easier (and what I have been coding while watching), since each operation (+, -, etc.) acts immediately on the last two numbers entered/calculated - no need to remember what function is intended for the next number entered. All you need to do is have an [Enter] key that pushes the currently displayed number onto a "stack" so that operations can act on the displayed value and the last number put on the stack.

topLevelComment.author: Gergő Árpád Borbély
topLevelComment.text: Hey everyone! At 3:15:19 you can type var.set("Off") or var.set("On"). Explenation: The checkbox does not set a default value by itself. When you make an IntVar(), the default value for an Integer (or number variable) is 0 which (to the checkbox) means false. So basically, you are giving the checkbox a default value, when you set the StringVar() to "Off". I hope this explenation was understandable. Have a good day!

replies.author: Hamza Naseer
replies.text:
Hey that star means importing everything from the tkinter library..
There are 3 different ways you can import libraries.
The only difference is that when you import  "*" you just have to write the name of the class/function/method you want to use e.g Button(..... ) whereas when you import Tkinter only... You'd use it as Tkinter.Button(...)

topLevelComment.text: For the bug in the checkboxes segment, instead of using c.deselect(), you can explicitly set the checkbox to either checked or unchecked with var.set("On") or var.set("Off"), respectively, right under var = StringVar() and it will also workaround said bug.

replies.author: raphiam817
replies.text: Excellent suggestion!  It's pretty clear that that tkinter cannot provide a default when you are customizing. So, there is no real bug. Seems that the  practice is to always set the default using var.set(default_value) as you suggest.

topLevelComment.author: rajesh joshi
topLevelComment.text:
from tkinter import *

root = Tk()
root.title("Simple Calculator")

e = Entry(root, width=35, borderwidth=5)
e.grid(row=0, column=0, columnspan=3, padx=10, pady=10)


# e.insert(0, "")

def button_click(number):
    # .delete(0, END)
    current = e.get()
    e.delete(0, END)
    e.insert(0, str(current) + str(number))


def button_clear():
    e.delete(0, END)


def button_add():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "addition"
    f_num = float(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)


def button_subtract():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "subtraction"
    f_num = float(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)


def button_multiply():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "multiplication"
    f_num = float(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)


def button_divide():
    first_number = e.get()
    global f_num
    global math
    math = "division"
    f_num = float(first_number)
    e.delete(0, END)


def button_equal():
    second_number = e.get()
    e.delete(0, END)
    if math == "addition":
        e.insert(0, f_num + float(second_number))
    elif math == "division":
        e.insert(0, f_num / float(second_number))
    elif math == "multiplication":
        e.insert(0, f_num * float(second_number))
    else:
        e.insert(0, f_num - float(second_number))



# Defining the Buttons

button_1 = Button(root, text="1", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(1))
button_2 = Button(root, text="2", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(2))
button_3 = Button(root, text="3", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(3))
button_4 = Button(root, text="4", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(4))
button_5 = Button(root, text="5", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(5))
button_6 = Button(root, text="6", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(6))
button_7 = Button(root, text="7", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(7))
button_8 = Button(root, text="8", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(8))
button_9 = Button(root, text="9", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(9))
button_0 = Button(root, text="0", padx=40, pady=20, command=lambda: button_click(0))

button_add = Button(root, text="+", padx=39, pady=20, command=button_add)
button_subtract = Button(root, text="-", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_subtract)
button_multiply = Button(root, text="*", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_multiply)
button_divide = Button(root, text="/", padx=40, pady=20, command=button_divide)
button_equal = Button(root, text="=", padx=87, pady=20, command=button_equal)
button_clear = Button(root, text="Clear", padx=79, pady=20, command=button_clear)

# Put the buttons on the screen
button_1.grid(row=3, column=0)
button_2.grid(row=3, column=1)
button_3.grid(row=3, column=2)

button_4.grid(row=2, column=0)
button_5.grid(row=2, column=1)
button_6.grid(row=2, column=2)

button_7.grid(row=1, column=0)
button_8.grid(row=1, column=1)
button_9.grid(row=1, column=2)

button_0.grid(row=4, column=0)
button_clear.grid(row=4, column=1, columnspan=2)

button_add.grid(row=5, column=0)
button_equal.grid(row=5, column=1, columnspan=2)

button_subtract.grid(row=6, column=0)
button_multiply.grid(row=6, column=1)
button_divide.grid(row=6, column=2)

root.mainloop()

def zero(f = None): return 0 if not f else f(0) def one(f = None): return 1 if not f else f(1) def two(f = None): return 2 if not f else f(2) def three(f = None): return 3 if not f else f(3) def four(f = None): return 4 if not f else f(4) def five(f = None): return 5 if not f else f(5) def six(f = None): return 6 if not f else f(6) def seven(f = None): return 7 if not f else f(7) def eight(f = None): return 8 if not f else f(8) def nine(f = None): return 9 if not f else f(9) def plus(y): return lambda x: x+y def minus(y): return lambda x: x-y def times(y): return lambda x: x*y def divided_by(y): return lambda x: x/y

topLevelComment.author: William Moore
topLevelComment.text:
With the "slider bars demo" (about 3 hours into the video), I noticed that under Raspbian Linux that in the "slide()" function, that when you do "my_label = Label(root, text=str(horizontal.get()) )", that the program will display a larger 3 digit number okay, but when you set it to a 1 or 2 digit number, that artifacts of the previous number remain on screen. For instance, if I move the slider to "250", click the button, it will display "250" in the label, but then if I move the slider back down to "7" and click the button, it will show "270" in the label. To fix this, I decided to try padding each side of the str() value I got back from horizontal.get() with two spaces and I found that this corrected the problem. Here's the corrected code:

def slide():
  my_label = Label(root, text="  " + str(horizontal.get()) + "  ")
  my_label.pack()

I'm not sure if this is also a problem with the Windows version of Tkinter, but if it is, this fix might work.

topLevelComment.author: Laurence Bunnage
topLevelComment.text:
On the whole it's a good starter video but there are a couple of things that really rub me up the wrong way.
A number of times you had an error and corrected it with the words 'you just have to do it this way' sic. without explaining why.


1) On the radiobutton example you added a command and then went to add a var in the function declaration with those 'just do it' words.  The reason you need to have var here is that the radiobutton calls the command including the currently selected radiobuttons value which you could process in the function.
2) With the database example you added the connect, cursor, commit, close calls to each function, again with the 'just do it' words.  The reason you have to do this is because your conn.close() statement is before the root.mainloop() call so the database is being closed before the functions have a chance to be called.  If you move the conn.close() after root.mainloop() then when you call the functions the database is still open and you don't have to reopen and close the database each time.


As a teacher, you really should know why you are doing something, as those you teach will learn to do things by rote and not learn to understand how something is really working.

These courses are offered for free and I greatly appreciate them. One bit of criticism I can offer is that when I'm trying to learn something, it makes it a lot harder to learn when I'm trying to keep up with the instructor. Lots of people can type fast, I can type very fast, over 100 words a minute, but when I'm trying to teach someone something, I understand that they don't know what it is I'm trying to teach and I slow down for them and allow them time to absorb the information I'm teaching.

Hello, at first, thanks for your tutorial! It's awesome :)
However, I got one little question... I want to print some Japanese on the GUI. I find that the tkinter support some of the utf-8 characters but not all (not the Japanese characters). How can I solve this problem?

replies.author: Alter Ego
replies.text:
You need to format the widget with a font that contains the Japanese characters. Also, utf-8 is an encoding method for writing to disk. What you mean is Unicode. In Python 3+, all strings are Unicode. On my machine (Canadian English) I have to use the font "Lucida Sans Unicode". If not I get mojibake (文字化け).
Now, from DeeL translator (and I hope it's no too funny!):
ウィジェットを日本語を含むフォントでフォーマットする必要があります。また、utf-8はディスクに書き込む際のエンコード方法です。 何が言いたいのかというと、Unicodeです。  Python 3+では、文字列はすべてUnicodeです。私のマシン（カナダ英語）では「Lucida Sans Unicode」というフォントを使う必要があります。 そうしないとmojibake (文字化け)になってしまいます。

topLevelComment.author: Bryan Oakley
topLevelComment.text: It's pronounced "tee-kay-enter". Tk stands for "tk", a graphical toolkit, and "inter" stands for "interpreter" because tkinter is an interpreter for tk. Also, "slapping" the call to grid on the end is a worst-practice. mylabel1.Label(...).grid(...) will set mylabel1 to None. If you assign the widget to a variable, it's pointless to call grid on the same line since the variable will always be None. You are starting people out on the wrong foot and setting them up for future bugs by showing an example like "mylabel1 = mylabel1.Label(...).grid(...)"

replies.author: Bryan Oakley
replies.text: @Inkjet Printer Yes, two separate lines. And I recommend creating the widgets with the same master as a group and then calling grid as a separate group. It's much easier to visualize the layout when all of your calls to grid are together for widgets with the same master .

Hi bro. I am big fan of your python videos and gone through all video and learnt a lot. i got stuck with assigning a number in slider to start question from that number.  i have more than 1000 questions which can not complete in one go.Need your help to start question from any random number selected in slider.


from csv import DictWriter

import tkinter as tk

from tkinter import ttk,font



win =tk.Tk()



q=['If yes, does the SOP mentioning the Record Retention Period for "Electronic Record"?', 'Does the Spread sheet Validation SOP have instructions for not using  uncontrolled, invalidated spread sheets for GMP purpose?', 'Is the procedure to define and ensure the availability of approved job responsibilities of the each staff available?', 'Is the procedure for Physical and Logical security available for server and media room? ', 'Is the procedure for Good PW Policy and Password Management available for Lab system?', 'Is the procedure for Good PW Policy and Password Management available for Mfg/Packing PLC/PLC-SCADA systems?', 'Is the procedure for Good PW Policy and Password Management available for Engineering PLC/PLC-SCADA systems?', 'Is the procedure for Good PW Policy and Password Management available for Enterprise Systems?', 'Is the procedure to define rationalized (i.e. Data storage capacity, No of analysis/batches processed, data security and Data criticality) data backup frequency available? ', 'Is the procedure for Data Archival and Retrieval available for Lab systems?']





scalea=tk.Scale(win,from_=0,to=len(q),orient=tk.HORIZONTAL)

scalea.grid(row=18,column=0,sticky=tk.E)

scalea.set(0)



a=scalea.get()



def set_next():

    global a

    if a < len(q)-1:

        action()

        a += 1

        lab["text"]= f"{a}. {q[a]}"

def set_prev():

    global a



    if a > 0:

        a -= 1

        lab["text"]= q[a]



ru2 = tk.Button(win, text="Previous Question", command=set_prev,fg="green", bg="yellow",font=("Arial",12,"bold"))

ru2.grid(column=0, row=15,sticky=tk.W,padx=100,pady=2)



lab = tk.Label(win, text=f"{a}. {q[a]}",font=("Arial",10),justify=tk.LEFT)

lab.grid(column=0, row=6,pady=1,sticky=tk.W)



def sel():

    selection="You have selected option:"+Answer.get()

    Label12=tk.Label(win)

    Label12.config(text=selection,font=("Arial,12"))

    Label12.grid(row=16,column=0,sticky=tk.W)





Remark_label=tk.Label(win,text="Remark(In Case of No or Partial):",font=("Arial,12"))

Remark_label.grid(row=11,column=0,sticky=tk.W)



Answer=tk.StringVar()

Yes_radiobutton=ttk.Radiobutton(win,text="Yes",value="Yes     ",variable=Answer,command=sel)

Yes_radiobutton.grid(row=7,column=0,sticky=tk.W)



No_radiobutton=ttk.Radiobutton(win,text="No",value="No      ",variable=Answer,command=sel)

No_radiobutton.grid(row=8,column=0,sticky=tk.W)



Partial_radiobutton=ttk.Radiobutton(win,text="Partial",value="Partial",variable=Answer,command=sel)

Partial_radiobutton.grid(row=9,column=0,sticky=tk.W)



ru = tk.Button(win, text="Next Question", command=set_next,fg="green", bg="yellow",font=("Arial",12,"bold"))

ru.grid(column=0, row=0,sticky=tk.W,padx=100)



def action():

    Ans = Answer.get()

    question=q[a]



    with open("question.csv","a",newline="") as f:

        dict_writer=DictWriter(f,fieldnames=["Questions","Answer"])

        dict_writer.writerow({

        "Questions":question,

        "Answer": Ans,

        })



win.mainloop()

replies.text: Very few people are going to sift through your issue on YouTube. A far better option would be to post the question/s to Stack Overflow - its helped me a lot, and usually the community is very quick to teach you a better/more optimal way of doing something. Good luck!

topLevelComment.text:
I was looking at the Entry portion of the code.  I noticed that Button allows for a call back function when the button is clicked, but there is no call back for the Entry when the return key is hit or the .get() function is done.   Is a Button always required to accept or process the data from an entry?  I would hope there would be an option like the return key.
I figured it out.  I need to use the Entry.bind() method to bind the entry's return key to a callback function

replies.author: Bryan Oakley
replies.text: It's easy to make it look clunky but it's possible to make it look fairly modern with just a little extra effort, by using the themed widgets that come with tkinter.
